comment.author: 58654589@N08
comment.text: transcription:  "A.(?) [...?] Odell"

comment.author: 65030572@N05
comment.text: "A.J. Odell" This is the signature of Andrew J. Odell (November 30, 1832 -- November 23, 1903), a book collector of note who was born in Wurtsboro, Sullivan County, New York; grew up in Cuylerville, Livingston County, New York; and spent his adult life in New York City, where he died. His obituary in the New York Times, November 24, 1903, was as follows [1]: "Andrew J. Odell "Andrew J. Odell, who was formerly Secretary and Treasurer of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, died yesterday morning at 135 West Seventy-fifth Street, where he had lived for many years with his brother, Hamilton Odell. He was born in Wurtsboro, Sullivan County, this State, on Nov. 30, 1832. He came to this city in 1853 and worked for a year for the Erie Railroad, when he entered the service of the Lackawanna Road. For many years he held the position of Secretary and Treasurer. In the Summer of 1877, Mr. Odell became incapacitated for business as the result of a serious illness, and has been an invalid ever since. About ten days ago he had a cerebral hemorrhage, which caused his death. "Mr. Odell was an ardent book collector and connoisseur, and the sale of his fine library in 1880 created a good deal of interest among book lovers. Lyman Odell, his father, was at one time prominent in State politics." The papers of Andrew J. Odell, in 7 volumes, are housed at the library of the New York Historical Society. The following description is given of them (and him) in the library's catalog [2]: "Notes: Summary: Commonplace books, poetry, copies of letters, and private library catalogs, 1850-[186-], of Andrew J. Odell of Cuylerville, New York, and New York City. Commonplace books contain quotes and excerpts in English and French, probably copied during the 1860's, from a wide range of prose and poetical works on a variety of subjects. Catalogs of books from Odell's extensive private library include three volumes listing the author, title, place and date of publication, physical format, and subject matter of individual books from Odell's collection, with some entries additionally including the cost of the volume or bibliographical annotations recording the presence of plates, the rarity of the item, large paper copies, etc. Volume of poems, 1850 Mar.-1851, contains poetry signed, edited, and evidently composed by Andrew J. Odell as a young man residing in Cuylerville and Temple Hill, Livingston County, New York. Also included is a volume entitled "Pantagraphs" containing copies of letters, 1853-1857, by Odell to "Q" and A . Scott," and chiefly concerning his literary, philosophical, and humorous observations and reflections. Historical Note: Book collector, resident of Cuylerville, New York, and New York City. " This description is generally consistent with Andrew J. Odell's obituary -- the earliest poems of his in this collection are from 1850, when he would have been 17 years old. It is also consistent with U.S. Census records, which show Andrew Odell, age 17, in the household of his father, Lyman Odell, in the 1850 U.S. Census for the town of Leicester in Livingston County, New York State. [3] Cuylerville is a hamlet outside Leicester. This description of his papers also mentions a 3-volume catalog of Andrew J. Odell's book collection. This catalog was published prior to the sale, at auction, of his collection on November 18, 1878 by Bang's auction house in New York City (a second auction was apparently held on March 15, 1880). The title of the catalog was "Bibliotheca Curiosa: Catalogue of the Library of Andrew J. Odell," prepared by George P. Philes. Two of these volumes (Volume I published in 1878 and Volume II published in 1879) have been digitized by Google books [4,5]. By the end of volume II, 2434 books were cataloged. This was quite a major undertaking (as will be seen below). Volume I of the catalog of Odell's collection has a short foreword about the collection that describes Odell as the "present owner," indicating that he was alive at the sale of his collection. For purposes of the above inscription, though, the foreword also mentions that Andrew J. Odell personally signed nearly every book he owned (see text which I bolded for emphasis): "A large proportion of the books in this Catalogue offer unquestionable evidence that the present owner was not merely the collector of a most curious and valuable library, but that he was a diligent and critical reader of the books he collected; and it is presumed their intrinsic value is, in no small degree, enhanced by the numerous and learned MS. notes which many of them contain. It is proper to remark that the owner's autograph will be found in nearly every volume." Interestingly, the catalog itself became a collectors item of sorts, and when a copy was sold at auction many years later, here is what a contemporary account in the New York Times, April 8, 1890, had to say about it: "The catalogue of the library of Andrew J. Odell, which cost the owners of the library the entire proceeds of its sale, brought $425. It took the cataloguer three years to do his work." [6] The catalog of his collection might have been entitled "Bibliotheca Curiosa," but selling a whole collection of rare books and not even making a profit over the preparation of the catalog is even more curious! Andrew J. Odell has an author listing in the Library of Congress catalog in connection with the catalogs of his book collection [7], but no listing in its authority file. [1] query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F10B1EFB395E13... [2] aleph.library.nyu.edu/F/A1FNMTP1PDJI2JLHHM4UYG833LQRHK1LU... [3] familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.1/MCYY-2J3 [4] books.google.com/books?id=QktFAAAAYAAJ&printsec=front... [5] books.google.com/books?id=pEtFAAAAYAAJ&printsec=front... [6] query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F70F11F63E5D15... [7] lccn.loc.gov/13017952

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Ms. inscription: sambt einer vorred an Alle die [...] christum von her tzen lieb haben vnd des Anti christs vndoder bapts zu Rhom sambst seines anhangs abgesagte feind sein [Ms. correction to subtitle (note strike-throughs of subtitle and statement of responsibility, as well as correction to imprint date). The ms. subtitle is taken from a later edition of this work -- VD 16 L 1819 -- printed in Nuremberg in 1565 by Ulrich Neuber and Dietrich Gerlach.]

comment.text: Aus der Adam Späth'schen Sammlung zu Frankfurt a.M. der Stadtbibliothek gewidmet von Martin May. [Probably stamp of Stadtbibliothek Frankfurt am Main, who received a donation from city councilman Martin May (1822-1919; grandfather of architect Ernst May) of his brother-in-law Adam Späth's (d. ca. 1890; VIAF entry here) books.]

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Median folio(?) [leaf size: 310 x 214 mm.], printed in double columns. Unsigned leaf: 41 lines to a full column, plus headline ("Von der kunst cristi"); area of text: 246 (260) x 156 mm.; col. width: 73 mm. Two 2-line initial spaces with guide letters (initials supplied in red ms.). Spaces for 2 paragraph marks (supplied in red; section headings read: "Das vnser herre die werlt bestritte[n] hat. da sie an dem mechtigisten gewesen ist" and "Wie gelert vnd künstenreich leüt yn werltlichen künsten. in der werlt gewesenn seyen. vmb die zeit cristi vnsers herren."). (Capital strokes supplied in red.) Without signature, foliation or catchword. Very possibly from Schatzbehalter der wahren Reichtümer des Heils by Stephan Fridolin, O.F.M., printed in Nuremberg by Anton Koberger on 8 November 1491 (ISTC is00306000). Cf. this image. This Christie's auction catalog entry gives the following description: "Median 2° (335 x 235 mm). Collation: a-z6 ab-ad6 ae8 A-Z6 Aa-Gg6 Hh10 (a1 blank, a2r prologues, a4v text, Hh9r colophon, Hh9v-10 blank). 354 leaves. 40 lines and headline, double column, printed guide-letters."

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Positively identified as leaf A5 (recto visible) from Schatzbehalter der wahren Reichtümer des Heils by Stephan Fridolin, O.F.M., printed in Nuremberg by Anton Koberger on 8 November 1491 (ISTC is00306000). Cf. the facsimile ed. published as Schatzbehalter, v. 28 in the series The Printed Sources of Western Art, ed. T. Besterman (Portland, Or.: Collegium Graphicum, 1972).

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Woodcut coat of arms of Georg, Herzog von Bayern-Landshut (1455-1503) of the House of Wittelsbach, known as Georg der Reiche (George the Rich). (His marriage to Hedwig Jagiellon, daughter of King Casimir IV Jagiellon of Poland, in 1475 was immortalized as the Landshuter Hochzeit and is currently reenacted every four years by the citizens of Landshut.) Established heading: Georg, ǂc Herzog von Bayern-Landshut, ǂd 1455-1503.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Woodcut illustration (probably intended to represent Georg Zingel, the author Jacob Locher's nemesis) of a snake-haired figure (Medusa?) riding a horse shod with pattens. The figure carries a whip of snakes in its right hand and holds the horse's tail (which ends in a dragon's head) in its left; from behind its head project a boar's head and a dog's head.  Used by Johann Grüninger of Strasbourg.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Woodcut illustration of a verse retelling of the parable of Dives and Lazarus (Luke 16:19-31) by Jacob Locher. Used by Silvan Otmar of Augsburg.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Woodcut illustration of a verse retelling of the parable of Dives and Lazarus (Luke 16:19-31) by Jacob Locher. (Here the two meet Charon, the ferryman of the dead -- not a feature of the original parable, but hey ...)  Used by Silvan Otmar of Augsburg.

These border elements were first used by Hupfuff in Doctor murners narre[n] bschweru[n]g (1512). Cf. U. Kocher, Boccaccio und die deutsche Novellistik (Amsterdam: Rodopi, 2005), p. 391. (The element at right incorporating a pile of excrement at foot appears to be signed or captioned: FRIS D3.)

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: One of 21 woodcut illustrations (4 repeated), used here by Matthias Hupfuff of Strasbourg, of which 11 previously appeared in Die hystoria von Melusina (Hupfuff, 1506), 2 in Das bůch der geschücht des grossen Allexandrs (Strasbourg: Bartholomäus Kistler, 1503), 2 in Historia destructionis Troiae (Kistler, 1499), 1 in König Laurins Rosengarten (Hupfuff, 1500), and 1 in Das Bůch der Selen wurtzgarte[n] (Hupfuff, 1511). Cf. U. Kocher, Boccaccio und die deutsche Novellistik (Amsterdam: Rodopi, 2005), p. 390.

comment.author: 58558794@N07
comment.text:
From the bookseller's description laid in:
"An extremely interesting satirical work by the Alsatian humanist Ottmar Nachtgall called Luscinius (1487-1536), who was a jurist, a linguist, a musician and a theologian.  The book is an attack on obscurantism, written in the form of a dialogue between Misobarbus, the adversary of barbarians, and Grunnius, a sophist turned into a pig.  While the first one tries to prove that one of the principal causes of happiness is intellectual culture, the second one maintains that man will always be miserable and therefore lives best like an animal.  The woodcut on the title-page shows a horse charged with books, a poet laureate, and a pig on his hindlegs wearing a hat and a coat.  On the last 4 pages is the text of <u>M. Grunnii Corocottae porcelli Testamentum</u>, a satire first printed at Fano in 1505, which gave our book its title."

comment.author: 58654589@N08
comment.text: "Wessel & Stodart No. 1. Soho Square London Importers of ...": A publishing house founded by Chri[s]tian Rudolf Wessel in London. He began his editorial activity with William Stodart establishing the firm Wessel & Stodart which primarily concentrated only on importing musical prints, and from 1824 also on an independent publishing activity. In 1838 Stodart backed out of the partnership and Wessel continued on his own until 1839 when Frederic Stapleton joined him as partner. In 1845 Stapleton withdrew of the firm. In 1860 Wessel handed the business over to its administrators, Edwin Ashdown and Henry Parry, and the company continued under the imprint Edwin Ashdown Ltd. From 1833 Wessel's publishing house published Chopin's works, in 1836 it acquired exclusive right to publication of Chopin's compositions in Great Britain. The publishing house published mainly piano music, many popular arrangements of opera airs and dances, but it also printed piano compositions of Beethoven's, Mozart's (sonatas), Heller's, Thalberg's. Cf. en.chopin.nifc.pl/chopin/institutions/detail/id/1725 Wessel, Christian Rudolf, 1797-1885 viaf.org/processed/DNB|117313556

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Hiester H. Muhlenberg (1812-1886), American physician and financier. He took his MD from the University of Pennsylvania in 1833 and practiced medicine for a few years in Reading, PA. In 1842 he was elected cashier of the Farmers' Bank of Reading, which position he held until his death. He was a trustee of Muhlenberg College from 1868-1876 and presented the college with its first telescope. Cf. S.E. Ochsenford, ed., Muhlenberg College: A Quarter-Centennial Memorial Volume (Allentown, PA: Muhlenberg College, 1892), p. 174 and 259-260. Established form: Muhlenberg, H. H. ǂq (Hiester Henry), ǂd 1812-1886.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: "Henry Muhlenberg Junior" is probably to be identified with Henry Ernest Muhlenberg (or Gotthilf Heinrich Ernst Muhlenberg) (1753-1815), American Lutheran clergyman and botanist, son of Henry Melchior Muhlenberg (q.v.). Muhlenberg Jr. was the first president of Franklin College (later Franklin and Marshall), serving in that office from 1787 until his death. The bog turtle is named after him, at least in Latin (Glyptemys muhlenbergii). Established form: Muhlenberg, Henry, ǂd 1753-1815.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: "H M. Mühlenberg" is probably to be identified with Henry Melchior Muhlenberg (originally Heinrich Melchior Mühlenberg) (1711-1787), patriarch of the American Muhlenberg family and father of the Lutheran Church in the United States. Established form: Muhlenberg, Henry Melchior, ǂd 1711-1787.

comment.text: Library label of Springwood Park, Kelso, Scotland, formerly the estate of the Baronets Douglas of Maxwell. The land was purchased and renamed from Bridgend by Admiral Sir James Douglas in 1750; the house fell into disrepair under the 6th baronet, Sir James Louis Fitzroy Scott Douglas, and was torn down after his death in 1969 (the contents having been sold at auction to cover his debts).

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Line 3: en el tomo 8o Bibliothec[a]e Patrum [Probably a reference to Marguerin de la Bigne's Bibliothecae Patrum et Veterum Auctorum Ecclesiasticorum, published in 8 volumes in Paris in 1575 (with an additional volume in 1579 and expanding to 27 volumes by 1677). This was a seminal work of modern critical patristics, albeit with a mild polemical bent -- Bigne wanted to make sure the works of the Church Fathers were read correctly (i.e. in support of Catholic dogma, not Protestant).]

comment.author: 65030572@N05
65030572@N05
65030572@N05
comment.text: So, who wrote this inscription and when?  We are obviously dealing with a highly educated person - the French and script here are very well executed, and the author knows of (and cares about) rare manuscripts, even to the point of recounting a local Parisian controversy surrounding one of them.  That would suggest that he lived in Paris.  The Call Number accompanying this book gives the year 1692 -- presumably the year it was published.  Given that the inscription talks about a controversy involving Anthony Varillas as if Varillas were still alive, and and since Varillas died in 1696, it is quite likely that the inscription is as old as the book.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text:
Henry Houston Bonnell (1859-1926) was an 1880 Penn graduate (Class Prophet and recipient of the Spoon Award; cf. the Record for his year). After earning his BA, he worked for some years in publishing before retiring to concentrate on literary scholarship and philanthropy. His collection of works by and related to the Brontë family went after his death to the Brontë Parsonage Museum. A. Edward Newton, who advised both Bonnell and his widow to make the bequest, wrote of him:
Many years ago, nearer fifty than forty, I had a friend -- he is dead now -- who, like myself, was a member of a little club which devoted itself to the study of English literature. His name was Henry Houston Bonnell; unlike myself, he was not only pious, but good, really good. When I first knew him he was not rich, but he inherited wealth, and in between the various philanthropic activities to which he devoted his life he became a book-collector and a student of the English novel. He concealed from his friends -- at least from me -- the fact that he wrote hymns. I am glad of this. (Derby Day and Other Adventures (Boston: Little, Brown, 1934), p. 298-299)

comment.author: 65030572@N05
65030572@N05
65030572@N05
comment.text: "En parlant du Florentin Poggio, Il assure qu'il avoit trouvé chez Un Epicier Almand les Institutions et les XIX Primieres Declamations de Quintilian+ [+et que c'était le seul exemplaire que fut au monde]. Il nous a assurement decouvert un grand Tresor en nous donnant Quintilian mais si l'Epicier almand l'avoit dechiré comme il doit prêt à le faire. Cette perte n’eut pas été irreparable. Un beau MS qui je trouve dans la riche Bibliothequo de Oxford de plus Cinque Cens Ans auroit console le Publique du Malheur aussi bien que plusieure autres...” “In speaking of the Florentine Poggio, he [presumably Varillas] affirms that he [Poggio] had found at the house of a Swiss grocer the Institutions and the first 19 Declamations of Quintilian [marginal note: and this was the only example which was in the world]. He surely discovered a great treasure in giving us Quintilian especially if the Swiss grocer had torn it up as he supposedly was about to do. This loss would not have been irreparable. A nice manuscript which I found in the rich library of Oxford, of more than 500 years, would have consoled the public of the misfortune, as well as many others...” The reference to the Declamations in this paragraph is to two sets of Declamations attributed to Quintilian, which have also survived. Some of these are thought to be spurious and others are attributed to a student of Quintilian and written in his style. The dramatic scene of Poggio discovering a treasured manuscript just at the very point when a Swiss grocer was going to tear it to shreds fits with the criticism of Varillas for embellishing his historic tales. This inscription is continued on the verso side of the sheet, also in this photostream, where the sentence at the bottom of this page is continued. The last word on this page is duplicated at the beginning of the next.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Armorial bookplate of John King Van Rensselaer (1847-1909), president of the Stirling Fire Insurance Company. His wife, Mrs. John King Van Rensselaer (née May Denning King) (1848-1925), was an author of works on cultural history. In 1917 she addressed the New York Historical Society and called its meetings "uninteresting and dull" and the building which housed its collections, "a deformed monstrosity filled with curiosities, ill-arranged and badly assorted." Her suggestions for improving these conditions, receiving no support at the meeting, were referred to a committee. (Cf. "Tells Historical Society It Is Dead," New York Times 3 January 1917).

He also held a staff appointment at Reading Hospital. Cf. his entry in M.L. Montgomery, Historical and Biographical Annals of Berks County, Pennsylvania (Chicago: J.H. comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Possibly R[obert]. M. Baltzer (ca. 1813-1838), assistant surgeon in the U.S. navy. He took his M.D. from the National Medical College of the Columbian University (later George Washington University), Washington, D.C., in 1832. He served on the United States and the Delaware from 1832-1836, when he was ordered "to the Hospital at Philadelphia" (Army and Navy Chronicle, n.s., v. 2 (1836), p. 288), probably the hospital associated with the Naval Asylum in Grays Ferry. On 15 February 1837 he was one of 18 surgeons and assistant surgeons to petition Congress for the establishment of the office of Surgeon General of the Navy (their petition did not succeed). He died in Washington, D.C., on 4 January 1838, "in the 26th year of his age ... of pulmonary consumption, leaving a mother and family of relatives, and a numerous circle of attached friends, to lament his premature dissolution," according to the Washington Daily National Intelligencer (5 January 1838).

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Bookplate of Charles B. Foote (1837-1900), American banker and book collector. Evidently he was a better collector than broker; his firm Hatch and Foote failed during a panic in 1884 and at the time of his death his partner Daniel Hatch accused him of unauthorized speculation with the firm's funds, leading to a second collapse (cf. the Lewiston Daily Sun, 19 September 1900). Cf. also his death notice in the New York Times (21 September 1900), sub-headlined "Ruined Stock Broker Passes Away Without Regaining Consciousness". A portion of his library was sold at auction in 1894 and a catalog published, Catalogue of the Unique Collection Made by Charles B. Foote, Esq. ... To be sold at auction Friday, November 23, 1894 at 3 p.m. by Bangs & Co. (New York: 1894-1895). Established heading: Foote, Charles B., ǂd 1837-1900.

comment.author: 58880069@N07
comment.text:
This is probably the autograph of Francis St John (1634-1705), an English lawyer, historian and politician who built up a library of history books at his home at Longthorpe, UK. Apparently a painting with a portrait of Francis St John, originally stored at his home Thorpe Hall, in Peterborough was moved to Kimbolton Castle in the 18th century and then sold at the sale of Kimbolton Castle by the earl of Manchester in 1949. It is possible that Francis St John's library  may have been moved to Kimbolton Castle as well, which would explain why his autograph appears together with the bookplate of the Castle in more than 1 book.
He's not established in VIAF.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text:
Bleah. I see two ms. ownership inscriptions, the first in a pretty legible hand:
Ad vsu[m] fr[atr]is Pauli antonij quo[n]da[m?] natalis [...] mariani de mo[n]ticiano or[dinis]: E[remita][rum]: s[anc]ti: Augustini
I can't make out the first word on the second line -- I think what the Latin is trying to get across is that Brother Paolo Antonio was born something-or-other Mariano, but bedoggoned if I can turn the letters into anything relevant. (I'm guessing a macron has been omitted at the end of "quo[n]da[m?]"). That said, the Augustinian house at Monticiano (a town near Siena) was founded ca. 1288; cf. F. Andrews, The Other Friars (Woodbridge: Boydell, 2006), p. 107. The Romanesque church (Chiesa di Sant'Agostino) and now former monastery (Convento di Sant' Agostino) are tourist attractions, notable for their frescoes. Neither house nor church is established. The second hand is much less neat and blotted in unfortunate places. This guy writes in two columns, a purchase note on the left:
est Michaelis Angeli de[?] Millot[...] emptus ab ipso [...]issj[?] d[...] libris cu[m] dimidio.
The second word in the last line can't be "ad" -- note the looped ascender on all the other miniscule ds. Also, I'd bet my hat on "dimidio" in the ablative here. The right-hand column is a straightforward (!!) ownership inscription:
Michalangelus [corr. to: Michaelangelus] Millot sius[?] Clustinensis hunc possidet libru[m]
I think it's "Millotsius" -- probably an attempt to Latinize the surname "Millot". Unfortunately the corresponding ending in the other inscription is blotted beyond my ability to make it out. "Clustinensis" doesn't seem to be anywhere obvious, either. Bah, humbug.

est Michaelis Angeli de[?] Millot[...] emptus ab ipso [...]issj[?] d[...] libris cu[m] dimidio.
The second word in the last line can't be "ad" -- note the looped ascender on all the other miniscule ds. Also, I'd bet my hat on "dimidio" in the ablative here. The right-hand column is a straightforward (!!) ownership inscription:
Michalangelus [corr. to: Michaelangelus] Millot sius[?] Clustinensis hunc possidet libru[m]
I think it's "Millotsius" -- probably an attempt to Latinize the surname "Millot". Unfortunately the corresponding ending in the other inscription is blotted beyond my ability to make it out. "Clustinensis" doesn't seem to be anywhere obvious, either. Bah, humbug.

From F.R. Karl and L. Davies, eds., The Collected Letters of Joseph Conrad (Cambridge: Cambridge UP, 1983-2007), v. 7, p. xlvii-xlviii:
Virginia-born Meredith Janvier (1872-1936), after graduating in law from the University of Maryland, practised in a Baltimore firm for thirteen years, whereupon he abandoned law to become a photographer. He was also an amateur strongman. Some twenty years later he again changed professions, becoming a manuscript and rare-book dealer. A contributor to the Baltimore Evening Sun, he published two collections of essays, Baltimore in the Eighties and Nineties (1933) and the posthumous Baltimore Yesterdays (1937), the latter with a preface by his friend H.L. Mencken.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: The Crispolti appear to have been a Perugian family. This book-owning scion has an unenlightening entry ("Crispolti, Metelli, et amicorum") in the IPI. A letter dated 3 January 1585 from a Metello Crispolti to a correspondent in Rome regarding the ordering and borrowing of books is recorded among the mss. of the Biblioteca Augusta in Perugia (cf. G. Cecchini, La Biblioteca Augusta del comune di Perugia (Rome: Edizione di storia et letteratura, 1978), p. 355). Given that this edition of Girolamo Borro's De peripatetica docendi atque addiscendi methodo was printed in 1584, I'm thinking there's a strong possibility that the two might be one and the same person.

comment.author: 58558794@N07
comment.text: In this History of Bettona a Metello Crispolti is mentioned as having been tortured by Gian Paolo Baglioni who was commanding part of Cesare Borgia's army as it sacked its way through Umbria. (Crispolti broke.) The tortured Crispolti is almost certainly not the Metello of our inscription since the book it appears in was published in 1584 and Borgia's troops were pillaging in the very early 1500s. But we do have a known family and location to work with now so it may be possible to pin some dates on our Metello.

comment.text: Woodcut of St. Paul at his writing table. (The two swords crossed in saltire beneath the writing figure's feet are an image commonly associated with St. Paul, particularly in heraldry.)  The figure seated at left interests me:  I can't quite make out what he's holding (a bow, maybe?) nor can I determine what kind of animal is lying on the sill in front of him (dog? cat? very small lion?).  I suspect him of being Paul's jailer and the whole a representation of the saint writing from prison.  Used by Hans Lufft of Wittenberg.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Stamp of Engelhard-Reyher'sche Hofbuchdruckerei, Gotha, Germany, lineal descendant of the press run by Andreas Reyher (1601-1673) and his heirs since the mid-17th century. In 1808 Georg Engelhard married into the family and by 1823 had earned a partnership. Cf. the entry for Paul Matthaei, a later director of the firm, at the Gotha city website. Per CERL's entry for Georg Engelhard, after 1843 the name "Engelhard-Reyher'sche Hofbuchdruckerei" was officially adopted.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Bookseller's label of G.E. Stechert & Co., New York. The firm was founded in 1872 by Gustav E. Stechert (1840-1899) as Stechert and Wolff; on Wolff's retirement in 1876 it became known as G.E. Stechert. In 1897 Stechert took Alfred Hafner (1866-1954) into partnership, but the firm continued under the same name until 1904, when it became G.E. Stechert & Co. (Cf. Gustav Stechert's obituary in The Publisher's Weekly for 7 October 1899, p. 671, and this notice of the name change in the same publication on 3 September 1904, p. 397). Hafner became sole owner of the firm in 1914 and its name was changed to Hafner-Stechert in 1946. Cf. Hafner's obituary in The New York Times, 15 April 1954, p. 29. Established form: G.E. Stechert & Co.

comment.text:
This is not the bookplate of John Rolle, but of his adopted heir, Hon. Mark George Kerr Rolle (1835–1907) (born Trefusis).
The arms are those of Rolle, Clinton, and Trefusis.

David Shaw (Canterbury)

comment.author: 13631645@N03
comment.text:
I've changed my mind -- the arms are indeed those of Rolle, Clinton and Trefusis, but John Rolle's second wife was Louisa Trefusis who was a descendant of the Clinton line.
So the arms are as likely to be those of John Rolle as of his nephew Mark.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Since the associated bookplate is that of Theodorus Bailey Myers Mason (1848–1899), who was born Myers but took the surname Mason at the request of his maternal grandfather Sidney Mason (1799-1871), this plate is also likely to be associated with Sidney Mason's family. (His daughter Catalina, Theodorus's mother, was boarding at the Ursuline convent in Charlestown, Massachusetts, at the time of the riots and was rescued by the grandfather of Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr.'s wife Fanny. Reportedly, he dropped Catalina over a wall into a potato patch.)

comment.author: 67856226@N08
comment.text: Born Harriet Corning Turner, in Troy, New York, 18 June 1822. Attended a fancy school for girls in New York City run by a French refugee from the revolution. In 1840 she married John Van Schaick Lansing Pruyn (1811-1877), an Albany lawyer and in the later part of his life the Chancellor of the University of the State of New York, which is New York's accreditation body. He served in the New York State Senate starting in 1861 and then did two stints as a Democrat in the US Congress from 1863-5 and 1867-9.  She traveled extensively with her husband throughout Europe and the Near East, and took particular interest in sites of biblical or general religious interest. She died on March 22, 1859, and appears to have been fairly well known and respected in her circles for being an interesting and well-traveled character.

comment.author: 67771791@N06
comment.text: The detail of this plate visible at luna-insight.smith.edu:8180/luna/servlet/detail/PRATTPRT~... shows it to have been designed by Hollyer and dated 1907. This must be the plate of the second Mrs. Pruyn, Anna Fenn Parker (March 26, 1840-October 7, 1909), the first having died in 1859.

comment.author: 67771791@N06
comment.text: The leading "Revd Dr Sprague" in greater New England at this time was William Buell Sprague (1795-1876) .  He was a well-known collector of autographs (100,000+).  In 1865, the time of this inscription, he held the pupil of Second Presbyterian Church in Albany, N.Y.  Given that the bookplate also in this book is that of an owner of Albany, this is likely the recipient.  For more on Sprague see the finding aid for a collection of his papers at the Litchfield Historical Society.  His collection of 20,000+ pamphlets is at the Princeton Theological Seminary.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Eberhard Bidenbach* (1528-1597) was a German Lutheran theologian from a family of them; cf. their collective entry in the ADB. He received his doctorate in theology from the University of Tübingen in 1557 and served as abbot of Bebenhausen (a Cistercian house; he succeeded the last Roman Catholic abbot in 1560), as well as a councillor to Herzog Christoph of Württemberg. He married Sophie, daughter of Johann Brenz (another Lutheran theologian), and helped edit Brenz's works after his death. He had five children, among them Eberhard Bidenbach the Younger and Johannes Bidenbach. He has a VIAF entry. *German Wikipedia gives his name as Eberhard Bidembach der Ältere.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Johann Bidenbach* was a German jurist. The son of Eberhard Bidenbach, he was born ca. 1561 (per German Wikipedia; DNB gives his dates as "fl. 1586-1588") and achieved his J.U.D. from the University of Tübingen in 1591. He served as Landschaftsadvokat from 1591 and Hofgerichtsassessor for Tübingen from 1595, but in 1596 he was dismissed from these positions and briefly imprisoned. His subsequent career is obscure; he probably died in the first quarter of the 17th century. He has a VIAF entry. *German Wikipedia gives his name as Johann Bidembach.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: According to B. Tolley, Pastors and Parishioners in Württemberg during the Late Reformation, 1581-1621 (Stanford: Stanford UP, 1995), p. 127, Jeremias Neobolus (or Neuheller) was the son of Johann Neobolus (1542-1610), pastor of Entringen (near Tübingen), and served as pastor in Pfäffingen (also near Tübingen) from 1624-1632. (His grandfather, Jodocus or Jost Neobolus (d. 1572) was also pastor at Entringen and evidently Martin Luther's steward.)

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Ex libri[s?] Andrea[e?] Martij. [The name is fairly common, but a "Dominus Andreas Martius Augustanus" is on the matriculation list of the University of Bologna for the year 1560; cf. E. Friedlaender and C. Malagola, eds., Acta Nationis Germanicae Universitatis Bononiensis ex archetypis tabularii Malvezziani (Berlin: G. Reimer, 1887), p. 338. This would be Andreas Mertz of Augsburg (d. 1603), son of Wilhelm Mertz (1467-1559) and his second wife Afra Rem (d. 1578); cf. E. Gebele, "Augsburg Bibliophilen," Zeitschrift des Historischen Vereins für Schwaben und Neuburg, Bd. 52 (1936), p. 54, note 110. According to G.C. Knod, Deutsche Studenten in Bologna (1289-1562) (Berlin: Decker, 1899), no. 2294, Mertz married Felicitas Welserin in 1562. (She was the daughter of Leonhard Welser and Sybille Hemmerlin and granddaughter of Bartholomeus Welser the Elder, Augsburg banker and privy counsellor of Charles V, who financed the conquest of Venezuela. Cf. Grosses vollständiges Universal-Lexicon aller Wissenschafften und Künste (Halle: J.H. Zedler, 1732-1750), entry Welser.) According to Gebele, Mertz possessed an extensive and comprehensive library whose catalog "findet sich noch in der Augsburger Stadtbibliothek (2o Cod. Aug. 381)" (p. 28). He thus seems a likely candidate for ownership of this book.]

comment.author: 58584977@N05

G.C. Knod, ed., Die Alten Matrikeln der Universität Strassburg, 1621 bis 1793 (Strassburg: K.J. Trübner, 1897-1902), Bd. 1, p. 380.]

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Sum Martini Jost Vallesiani 1571. Omnibus via lae[...] [Possibly Martin Jost (d. 1612)? The toponymic "Vallesianus" refers to the canton of Wallis or Valais in Switzerland. According to F. Meyer, "Andreas Ryff (1550-1603), Liber Legationum" in Baseler Zeitschrift für Geschichte und Altertumskunde, Bd. 58/59 (1959), p. 97, n. 300, Martin Jost of Ernen in Valais was Meier (bailiff) of Goms in 1580-1584 and 1609, Bannerherr (captain of militia?) of Goms 1597-1605, and Landvogt (reeve) of Monthey 1590-1591. According to C. Schnyder in Reformation und Demokratie im Wallis (1524-1613) (Mainz: Philipp von Zabern, 2002), Jost was deposed as Bannerherr of Goms in late November 1603 for suspected Reformed tendencies (perhaps evidenced by his ownership of this book by Melanchthon). A mob came to his house to demand that he surrender the banner that symbolized his captaincy; Jost was not at home, but his wife Katharina handed it over. On the following day Jost appeared in public to unsuccessfully defend his position and his orthodoxy; Matthäus Schiner (one of the men to whom Katharina Jost had given the banner) succeeded Jost as Bannerherr. Ironically, according to S. Furrer, Geschichte von Wallis (Sitten: Calpini-Albertazzi, 1850), p. 320, Jost was executed in 1612 for treating with Spanish Milan in defiance of the Landrat (earning him the epithet "ein jesuitischer Fanatiker" in S. Hidber, "Kampf der Walliser gegen ihre Bischöfe" in Archiv des Historischen Vereins des Kantons Bern, Bd. 8.4 (1875), p. 534). The house Jost built in Ernen in 1581 is a tourist attraction today, the Jost-Sigristen House.]

comment.text: "Ex libris bibliot. Sac. Conuentus Assisii": label of the library of Sacro convento di S. Francesco (Assisi, Italy). Famous library built around 1239 as part of a complex also comprising a church and a monastery. For the first 200 years of its existence, the library rivaled the Sorbonne and Avignon with a comparable number of manuscripts. Established as: Sacro convento di S. Francesco (Assisi, Italy).
